I wish the more than 200 athletes on @TeamUSA the best ‚Äì and I pray they stay safe while they are away from home.¬†üá∫üá∏ üá∫üá∏ üá∫üá∏
The next time a host country is chosen, it is important that the IOC pick any of the dozens of democracies around the world.

The Olympic Committee could have required China to respect the basic liberties athletes enjoy in the United States and other Western countries.
¬†
But they didn‚Äôt.
This all could have been avoided. We didn‚Äôt have to host a unifying event like the Olympics in a country that thinks the book 1984 is an instruction manual.

The U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee¬†has gone as far as to tell American athletes to ‚Äúassume that every device and every communication, transaction, and online activity will be monitored‚Äù, and many other nations have issued similar warnings.

They had years to plan for these Olympics. But they still chose not to adopt any rules to protect the human rights of Olympians while they are in China. Instead, competitors are required to follow local laws limiting free expression, privacy, and other basic freedoms.
We shouldn‚Äôt pretend that everything is fine in China just because the IOC chose them to host the Olympics.
If this is how China treats its own people, I think it‚Äôs fair to ask: What kind of risks are our athletes facing as they participate in the Olympic Games?
Her existence was scrubbed from the internet. She disappeared from the public eye for months, and the only appearances she has been allowed to make since have been scripted and supervised by the CCP.

This wasn‚Äôt just any politician: He was the face of China‚Äôs successful effort to land the 2022 Olympics. Speaking out about someone like this is dangerous in a country like China. Peng Shuai knew that ‚Äì but I don‚Äôt think she expected what came next.
Last November, one of the most famous athletes in China, tennis star Peng Shuai, posted on social media that a high-ranking politician in the Chinese Communist Party had sexually assaulted her.

The very same government that‚Äôs hosting the Olympics this week is putting innocent people in labor camps and subjecting them to forced sterilization, forced labor, and physical and psychological torture. This is genocide.
But make no mistake: Beijing 2022 is no ordinary Olympics.
The American athletes competing in the Olympics this year have earned their spots on Team USA. And I wish them the best as they compete against other athletes from around the world.

About to speak on the Senate floor in support of @TeamUSA athletes as they compete. I also will speak about why these games are no ordinary Olympics and highlight some of the atrocious actions of the Chinese government.

I urge my colleagues to think beyond the passions of the moment and do what‚Äôs best for our country in the long term.
 
Leave the filibuster in place. Democrats may want to use it again as soon as next year.

Bipartisanship would become a relic of the past.
 
I know Democrats don‚Äôt want that to happen. I don‚Äôt want it to happen, either.

The truth is that some of my Democratic colleagues want to remake the American system only in their own image, not considering the views of about half of our citizens.

To do that, they have to take an ax to the filibuster.
When Republicans were in the majority, we said we wouldn‚Äôt abolish the legislative filibuster, and we kept our word.

This is not a debate about some arcane Senate rule.
 
This is about protecting the rights of the minority in our democracy.
 
This is about providing stability and certainty to our people.

Democrats were perfectly happy to use the filibuster literally hundreds of times during the four years of the Trump presidency, when the Majority Leader was the Minority Leader and Republicans had even larger majorities in Congress.

But because the rules don‚Äôt allow them to pass their federal takeover of elections or any of their other reckless policies in a 50-50 Senate, many of my Dem colleagues are flip-flopping to oppose the filibuster.
The first part of that simply isn‚Äôt true. The right to vote is not under assault.
Their argument is that lawmakers in red states are trying to make it harder for people to vote, and so it‚Äôs necessary for Washington Democrats to take over election administration in all 50 states.
The American people voted for bipartisanship and compromise in the United States Congress, not a blanket mandate for progressives to reorganize American life as they see fit.

President Biden wants to pass a New Deal. In fact, the reckless spending the president is pushing for dwarfs the New Deal.

Back then the New Deal passed the on the back of Dem supermajorities, but today we have a 50-50 Senate and the Dem majority is razor thin.

Getting ready to join my GOP colleagues on the Senate floor to call out the Democrats on their efforts to abolish the filibuster.

The filibuster requires senators to reach out across the aisle to find consensus for the American voters. Eliminating or altering the filibuster would drastically change the way our government operates and would make our country less secure, stable, and certain about our future. https://t.co/KHXJhA3ueO
